content:
Nice clash.
It's a bit confusing since it's not actually an encoding (can't be decoded) nor is it how you would type the words, since "B" would be "22" not just "2".

I spent a bit of time in-clash trying to solve it as though it was the real thing, e.g. "Hello world" -> "44555555666 96667775553", before I realised that it was a simpler version.

Not sure how to reword the statement, but it would be good to make it a bit more clear?
"The keypad we will be using is the following:"
is a bit vague and doesn't explicitly say that we will replace any of "ABC" with "2", "DEF" with "3" etc.

There's another clash out there that does the full version, so it's good to have this simpler case too. :)

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash. I like how at first I read too quickly and glanced over the PQRS and WXYZ edge cases. This is why one needs to have a good eye.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I had a bit difficulty with understanding the statement at first, but during testing in IDE it became clear step by step through error solving, and in retrospect the statement does tell everything that I needed to know.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good short CoC üëçÔ∏è

Hello thepaqui - 
pour ma part je trouverais cela plus interessant si l on devait ajouter les repetitions de touche

ex : L = 555

et meme un / ou \ pour symboliser l attente entre 2 touches (relou que je suis)

l espace se faisait en general par un appui sur la touche 0 eventuellement pour complexifier encore :) (et les chiffres c etait globalement un appui de plus que le nombre de lettres de la touche )

Goal section
* Please mention that all other characters (spaces and other special characters such as : and ^) are not changed.

Thanks.
Je sais pas si √ßa ferait un peu trop pour un Clash of Code... Mais j'aime l'id√©e !
Thank you for your feedback! I'm glad that you found the subject comprehensive.
Thank you for your feedback! Indeed, I was worried about these 2 but I decided to stay true to how these old keypads (at least the ones I'm used to) did it.

It wouldn't do too much if you solved it with lists and not like you did.

In reality, we just had to copy paste your message to make a dictionary (hashmap in java), iterate over it and create a list with all the combinations.
An example in Python to solve the current one:
touchpads = ["ABC", "DEF", "GHI", "JKL", "MNO", "PQRS","TUV", "WXYZ"]
replacement_dict = {str(i): '_' for i in range(2, 10)}

for index, touchpad in enumerate(touchpads):
    for letter in touchpad:
        replacement_dict[letter] = str(index+2)

s = input().upper()
s = map(lambda x: replacement_dict.get(x, x), s)

print("".join(s))
--------------------------

To solve it as Lanzecki says:
touchpads = ["ABC", "DEF", "GHI", "JKL", "MNO", "PQRS","TUV", "WXYZ"]
replacement_dict = {str(i): '_' for i in range(2, 10)}

for index, touchpad in enumerate(touchpads):
    for i, letter in enumerate(touchpad):
        replacement_dict[letter] = str(index+2)*i

s = input().upper()
s = map(lambda x: replacement_dict.get(x, x), s)

print("".join(s))
